comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content:
This does not look like a suburban location.  I believe it is a rural location.

It was not unusual for rural cottages to have picket fences.  The fence to the right and left of the picket fence is a strained wire fence with corner straining posts cut from tree trunks, and the other fence posts of the wire fence are split from trunks, probably hardwood.  The wire fence at right has chicken wire strung across the lower half of the fence, although this is not of itself a sign of a rural location.

The fact that there are no other residences visible in the photograph does signify a rural location.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: This photograph shows three men, a young boy, and a younger girl. Two of the men can be identified in the following photograph which also shows three men, a young boy and a younger girl. It was probably taken on the same day: www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/3093483387/

comment.author: 34307192@N03
comment._content:
The house shows two fireplaces. I suppose one for the living room,or parlor,and the other  for the kitchen or perhaps a bedroom. The house has a gutter system.I see no lightning rods. It looks like the house is brick.The cover over the porch is something new to me.It seems to be of somekind of tin or canvas. The cover extends way past the end of the house?
Wonderful old pictures. Thank you.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Ol'redneckbassfisherman - We call that material over the porch "Corrugated iron". It is corrugated galvanised iron. It is still a common building material in Australia. It is thin, like tin, about 2mm to 3 mm thickness. The whole of the roof of the house shown is covered in corrugated iron sheets. The sections over the porch are bent into a partially curved and partially stright section called a "bullnose". You can read a bit more about it here: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corrugated_galvanised_iron See examples of it here: images.google.com.au/images?um=1&hl=en&q=corrugat... And get a good idea of bullnose corrugated iron here: images.google.com.au/images?um=1&hl=en&q=bullnose... Here is a particularly good example of a piece of bullnose roofing: images.google.com.au/imgres?imgurl=http://www.bullnoseroo...

comment.author: 34307192@N03
comment._content:
Yes, i am very familiar with what we call "tin Roofs''. In rural Texas in the 1940's that is about all i ever saw on a house. I still love to hear the rain on a tin roof. 
I see the corrugated or galvanised metal was devoloped in the 1820's. Like our lighting rods ,a salesmen could make a good living selling these metals and also windmills. 
thank you sir.

comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: "View of 'Donnybrook' at Bungowannah, near Albury, 1905 - 1915 "The house has been identified as 'Donnybrook' at Bungowannah, 15 km east of Albury. On the verandah are Ephraim Shipard and his children Stanley and Bessie, and the older man leaning on the fence is his father William Shipard. "Gwenda Morrision (née Shipard) has identified these photographs of her family and houses. The connection to the Phillips family is not known." – History Notes
